In 7 lessons we will cover the contents of chapter 5 (book 1!) and chapter 10 (book2!).

These chapters are about a variety of subjects: arithmetic, decimal numbers, using your calculator, percentages, ratios, proportionalities and graphs. These are topics you might already be familiar with.

You are going to work in pairs.

Together you are going to work through this wiki:

read, study, watch videos individually AT HOME and do exercises together IN CLASS.

As a pair, you need to hand in all exercises you have done in this wiki.

You also need to hand in your combined pifs for these chapters.

This should be done by ...(date)...

For this, you will get a mark.

It is very important to prepare for the lessons.

Remember that our , is a . in the UK & USA and our . is a ,!

So 1 million = 1,000,000 and not 1.000.000

From now on, you may often (not always!) use your calculator in Maths!

It is important to know how to properly use it. In this section we will discuss some of the most important features of your calculator.

Which calculator?

We advised you to buy a Casio fx-82EX:

Other Casio fx-82 calculators (such as fx-82ES or fx-82ES Plus) are fine, but we strongly advise you NOT to use a Casio fx-82MS.

Study these tips & tricks for using your calculator:

1. How to put it on: use the "on" button on the upper right.

(Want to put it off? You don't have to, the calculator will switch off automatically. But you can turn it off bij pushing shift (upper left) and then AC (off) in the middle, on the right (the coloured button on the right).

2. Your calculator knows the order of operations. As long as you use the calculator correctly, you don't have to bother about the order of operations! (Isn't that nice?!)

3. For entering decimal numbers, use the decimal point, which is next to the 0.

4. There are 2 minus signs on your calculator: try to find them!

(-) is used for entering negative numbers, for example: 10 : -2

- is used for subtraction, for example: 5-2

5. The great thing about these calculators is that they know about fractions! What is the fraction button, do you think?

You can find it above the (-) button:

You can enter a fraction using this button. Try to enter ¾. Use the left/right/up/down buttons in the top center to navigate on your screen!

You can also enter mixed numbers, like 2½. To do this, first type shift and then type the fraction button. You can now enter the numbers using the left/right/up/down buttons again.

Using the fraction-button, you can also enter difficult quotients (!) like the ones in exercise 24 on page 196 in your book (1)!

6. Another great feature is that this calculator will give exact answers when possible. Calculate 5 : 6. The answer is a fraction: 5/6! Do you want a decimal number instead? Type this button (above the coloured DEL button)! And type it again to go back to the fraction!

Another example: calculate 123:6. The answer is 41/2. This is an improper fraction. Want a mixed number? Type shift and then the SD button and there is 20½!

7. What if ...? If your calculator is acting strangely, then you probably changed the settings. If so, you have to reset your calculator. Inside the frontcover of your calculator there is often a short guide to help you do this. If not, google "instellingen" and your type of calculator on the internet and you will probably find the information you need!

items.content: Read theory B on page 207 and 208 of your book (1).

Read theory C on page 209 of your book (1).

And watch this MathAntics video about proportions:

Ratio's and proportionallity:

From 1 bottle you can pour 6 glasses of lemonade.

The ratio of bottles to glasses is 1 : 6.

If you have 4 times as many bottles, you can pour 4 times as many glasses.

The number of glasses is proportional to the number of bottles.

Inversely propotional quantities:

It takes 12 hours for 1 person to paint a house.

If I hire 2 persons, it will take only 6 hours to paint the house.

And if I hire 3 persons, it will only take ..... hours!

And if I hire 4 persons? And 6?

Here, the time to paint the house is inversely proportional to the number of persosn I hire.

If I hire twice as many persons, the painting is done in half the time!

If I hire three times as many persons, the painting is done in one third of the time!

If I hire four times as many persons, the painting is done in .............?!

Graphs are used to present information. Not with words, but in a figure, with a drawing or an image.

A graph is a short and visual way of presenting information.

If you were to present the same information with words, you would probably need many words, and it wouldn't be as clear!

§10.3 is about handling graphs.

Read theory A on page 198 of your book (2).

Pie charts are a special kind of graph, often used to present information in percentages.

Do exercise 16 and read theory C on page 196 of your book (2).

Print this worksheet. You need it to do exercise 17.

Rough graphs are graphs without any numbers marked on the axes.

In rough graphs, it is not about the numbers!

Still, there is a lot of information in a rough graph!
